standard_metadata.standard_description: Fluently multiply multi-digit whole numbers using the standard algorithm.

hints.content: Let's estimate the product by rounding the factors:  $\phantom{=} 29 \times 3{,}198 $  $\approx 30 \times 3{,}000$
Let's estimate the product by rounding the factors:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=} 84 \times 6{,}879\\\\ &\approx 80 \times 7{,}000 \end{align}$

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=} \blueD{80} \times \greenD{7{,}000}\\\\ &= (\blueD{8} \times \blueD{10})  \times (\greenD{7} \times \greenD{1{,}000})&\small\gray{\text{Factor out multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= (\blueD{8} \times \greenD{7})  \times (\blueD{10} \times \greenD{1{,}000})&\small\gray{\text{Group the multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= 56  \times 10{,}000 \end{align}$
Let's estimate the product by rounding the factors:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=} 48 \times 366\\\\ &\approx 50 \times 400 \end{align}$

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=} \blueD{50} \times \greenD{400}\\\\ &= (\blueD{5} \times \blueD{10})  \times (\greenD{4} \times \greenD{100})&\small\gray{\text{Factor out multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= (\blueD{5} \times \greenD{4})  \times (\blueD{10} \times \greenD{100})&\small\gray{\text{Group the multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= 20\times 1{,}000 \end{align}$
Let's estimate the product by rounding the factors:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=} 86 \times 904\\\\ &\approx 90 \times 900 \end{align}$

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=} \blueD{90} \times \greenD{900}\\\\ &= (\blueD{9} \times \blueD{10})  \times (\greenD{9} \times \greenD{100})&\small\gray{\text{Factor out multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= (\blueD{9} \times \greenD{9})  \times (\blueD{10} \times \greenD{100})&\small\gray{\text{Group the multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= 81\times 1{,}000 \end{align}$
Let's estimate the product by rounding the factors:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=} 589 \times 219 \\\\ &\approx 600 \times 200 \end{align}$

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=} \blueD{600} \times \greenD{200}\\\\ &= (\blueD{6} \times \blueD{100})  \times (\greenD{2} \times \greenD{100})&\small\gray{\text{Factor out multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= (\blueD{6} \times \greenD{2})  \times (\blueD{100} \times \greenD{100})&\small\gray{\text{Group the multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= 12  \times 10{,}000 \end{align}$
Let's estimate the product by rounding the factors:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=} 585 \times 56\\\\ &\approx 600 \times 60 \end{align}$

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=} \blueD{600} \times \greenD{60}\\\\ &= (\blueD{6} \times \blueD{100})  \times (\greenD{6} \times \greenD{10})&\small\gray{\text{Factor out multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= (\blueD{6} \times \greenD{6})  \times (\blueD{100} \times \greenD{10})&\small\gray{\text{Group the multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= 36\times 1{,}000 \end{align}$
Let's estimate the product by rounding the factors:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=} 665 \times53 \\\\ &\approx 700 \times 50 \end{align}$

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=} \blueD{700} \times \greenD{50}\\\\ &= (\blueD{7} \times \blueD{100})  \times (\greenD{5} \times \greenD{10})&\small\gray{\text{Factor out multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= (\blueD{7} \times \greenD{5})  \times (\blueD{100} \times \greenD{10})&\small\gray{\text{Group the multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= 35\times 1{,}000 \end{align}$
Let's estimate the product by rounding the factors:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=} 388 \times565 \\\\ &\approx 400 \times 600 \end{align}$

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=} \blueD{400} \times \greenD{600}\\\\ &= (\blueD{4} \times \blueD{100})  \times (\greenD{6} \times \greenD{100})&\small\gray{\text{Factor out multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= (\blueD{4} \times \greenD{6})  \times (\blueD{100} \times \greenD{100})&\small\gray{\text{Group the multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= 24  \times 10{,}000 \end{align}$
Let's estimate the product by rounding the factors:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=} 319 \times577 \\\\ &\approx 300 \times 600 \end{align}$

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=} \blueD{300} \times \greenD{600}\\\\ &= (\blueD{3} \times \blueD{100})  \times (\greenD{6} \times \greenD{100})&\small\gray{\text{Factor out multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= (\blueD{3} \times \greenD{6})  \times (\blueD{100} \times \greenD{100})&\small\gray{\text{Group the multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= 18  \times 10{,}000 \end{align}$
Let's estimate the product by rounding the factors:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=} 137\times 18\\\\ &\approx 100 \times 20 \end{align}$

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=} \blueD{100} \times \greenD{20}\\\\ &= (\blueD{1} \times \blueD{100})  \times (\greenD{2} \times \greenD{10})&\small\gray{\text{Factor out multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= (\blueD{1} \times \greenD{2})  \times (\blueD{100} \times \greenD{10})&\small\gray{\text{Group the multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= 2\times 1{,}000 \end{align}$
Let's estimate the product by rounding the factors:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=} 92\times 543\\\\ &\approx 90 \times 500 \end{align}$

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=} \blueD{90} \times \greenD{500}\\\\ &= (\blueD{9} \times \blueD{10})  \times (\greenD{5} \times \greenD{100})&\small\gray{\text{Factor out multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= (\blueD{9} \times \greenD{5})  \times (\blueD{10} \times \greenD{100})&\small\gray{\text{Group the multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= 45\times 1{,}000 \end{align}$
Let's estimate the product by rounding the factors:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=} 64\times 873\\\\ &\approx 60 \times 900 \end{align}$

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=} \blueD{60} \times \greenD{900}\\\\ &= (\blueD{6} \times \blueD{10})  \times (\greenD{9} \times \greenD{100})&\small\gray{\text{Factor out multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= (\blueD{6} \times \greenD{9})  \times (\blueD{10} \times \greenD{100})&\small\gray{\text{Group the multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= 54\times 1{,}000 \end{align}$
Let's estimate the product by rounding the factors:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=} 814\times 178\\\\ &\approx 800 \times 200 \end{align}$

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=} \blueD{800} \times \greenD{200}\\\\ &= (\blueD{8} \times \blueD{100})  \times (\greenD{2} \times \greenD{100})&\small\gray{\text{Factor out multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= (\blueD{8} \times \greenD{2})  \times (\blueD{100} \times \greenD{100})&\small\gray{\text{Group the multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= 16\times 10{,}000 \end{align}$
Let's estimate the product by rounding the factors:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=} 479\times 513\\\\ &\approx 500 \times 500 \end{align}$

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=} \blueD{500} \times \greenD{500}\\\\ &= (\blueD{5} \times \blueD{100})  \times (\greenD{5} \times \greenD{100})&\small\gray{\text{Factor out multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= (\blueD{5} \times \greenD{5})  \times (\blueD{100} \times \greenD{100})&\small\gray{\text{Group the multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= 25\times 10{,}000 \end{align}$
Let's estimate the product by rounding the factors:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=} 68 \times 5{,}439\\\\ &\approx 70 \times 5{,}000 \end{align}$

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=} \blueD{70} \times \greenD{5{,}000}\\\\ &= (\blueD{7} \times \blueD{10})  \times (\greenD{5} \times \greenD{1{,}000})&\small\gray{\text{Factor out multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= (\blueD{7} \times \greenD{5})  \times (\blueD{10} \times \greenD{1{,}000})&\small\gray{\text{Group the multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= 35\times 10{,}000 \end{align}$
Let's estimate the product by rounding the factors:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=} 292\times 438\\\\ &\approx 300 \times 400 \end{align}$

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=} \blueD{300} \times \greenD{400}\\\\ &= (\blueD{3} \times \blueD{100})  \times (\greenD{4} \times \greenD{100})&\small\gray{\text{Factor out multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= (\blueD{3} \times \greenD{4})  \times (\blueD{100} \times \greenD{100})&\small\gray{\text{Group the multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= 12\times 10{,}000 \end{align}$
Let's estimate the product by rounding the factors:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=} 1{,}379 \times38 \\\\ &\approx1{,}000 \times 40 \end{align}$

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=} \blueD{1{,}000} \times \greenD{40}\\\\ &= (\blueD{1} \times \blueD{1{,}000})  \times (\greenD{4} \times \greenD{10})&\small\gray{\text{Factor out multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= (\blueD{1} \times \greenD{4})  \times (\blueD{1{,}000} \times \greenD{10})&\small\gray{\text{Group the multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= 4\times 10{,}000 \end{align}$
Let's estimate the product by rounding the factors:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=} 7{,}288 \times 96 \\\\ &\approx 7{,}000 \times 100 \end{align}$

$\begin{align} &\phantom{=} \blueE{7{,}000} \times \goldE{100}\\\\ &= (\blueE{7} \times \blueE{1{,}000})  \times (\goldE{1} \times \goldE{100})&\small\gray{\text{Factor out multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= (\blueE{7} \times \goldE{1})  \times (\blueE{1{,}000} \times \goldE{100})&\small\gray{\text{Group the multiples of 10}}\\\\ &= 7  \times 100{,}000 \end{align}$
